Course: Ethos of Nursing and Professional Practice
Fundamental of Nursing Science (Basic Nursing Science)
Orientation to the Nutritionist Profession and Study Skill
Description: Introduce students to university community; different types of memories and how they work; principles of problem-based learning; the seven jump steps and problem solving; the role of the tutor in a tutorial session; giving feedback and reflection; learning styles; leading group discussion; learning and study skills; assessment methods; evaluation of learning; understand different nutrition professions and their roles in public health; code of conduct of a nutritionist; role of nutrition in general health;

Anatomy and physiology of the digestive tract; digestion of macronutrients and micronutrients; chewing, salivary secretion and swallowing; the processing of motility and secretion in the stomach; the process of secretion in the biliary system; the process motility, secretion and absorption in the small intestine; process of absorption, secretion and motility in the large intestine

Nutrition during pregnancy and lactation; nutrition during infancy; nutrition in childhood; nutrition in adolescence; nutrition in the adult years; nutrition in gaining; nutrient requirements and recommendation

Interventions and health risk indicators in the community and/or public will be covered as follows: chronic diseases of lifestyle (understand pathophysiology, prevention and management of nutrition-related diseases); malnutrition; oral health; micronutrients deficiencies; debilitating diseases (HIV & AIDS and Respiratory diseases (TB & pneumonia); diarrhea (types of diarrhea, causes diarrhea, treatment of diarrhea)

Course: Nutrition Epidemiology, Applied Research Methods and Ethics
Description: Understand concepts of nutritional epidemiology; objectives of nutritional epidemiology; types of epidemiology studies; biostatistics and measurements of disease profile in the communities; nutrition surveillance; importance of conducting research; understand various research methodologies; understand principles of scientific writing; design a research project using appropriate study design; role of demography in health and nutrition; Understanding of ethics in health research.

Course: Orientation to the Nutritionist Profession and Study Skill
Description: Introduce students to university community; different types of memories and how they work; principles of problem-based learning; the seven jump steps and problem solving; the role of the tutor in a tutorial session; giving feedback and reflection; learning styles; leading group discussion; learning and study skills; assessment methods; evaluation of learning; understand different nutrition professions and their roles in public health; code of conduct of a nutritionist; role of nutrition in general health;

Nutrition during pregnancy and lactation; nutrition during infancy; nutrition in childhood; nutrition in adolescence; nutrition in the adult years; nutrition in gaining; nutrient requirements and recommendation

Nutritional genomics; anthropometric assessment; dietary and clinical assessment; laboratory or biochemical assessment food-drug interactions; nutrition diagnosis and intervention; dietary supplementation; counselling theory and technique

Interventions and health risk indicators in the community and/or public will be covered as follows: chronic diseases of lifestyle (understand pathophysiology, prevention and management of nutrition-related diseases); malnutrition; oral health; micronutrients deficiencies; debilitating diseases (HIV & AIDS and Respiratory diseases (TB & pneumonia); diarrhea (types of diarrhea, causes diarrhea, treatment of diarrhea)

Course: Nutrition Epidemiology, Applied Research Methods and Ethics
Description: Understand concepts of nutritional epidemiology; objectives of nutritional epidemiology; types of epidemiology studies; biostatistics and measurements of disease profile in the communities; nutrition surveillance; importance of conducting research; understand various research methodologies; understand principles of scientific writing; design a research project using appropriate study design; role of demography in health and nutrition; Understanding of ethics in health research.

Collect data related to the research proposal developed in the third level; analyze and interpret data using appropriate tools; write the research report or min-dissertation following appropriate format.

The student will work in the food service unit applying principles of food management, planning and leading under supervision. The student will be placed in the food service unit for a period of eight weeks.

Student will be responsible for the promotion of nutritional health and prevention of nutrition-related disorders/ill health of groups, communities or population via sustainable and equitable improvements in the food and nutrition system.

Students will work at the community level with the aim of promoting the implementation of nutrition intervention programmes and associated skills which are critical for nutrition training at the community level.

Course: Orientation to PBL, Biokinetics and Recreation and Leisure Studies programme
Description: Introduces students to the three programs in the Center and to the teaching methodology adopted by the School of Health Sciences.

Course: Foundation of Human Movement Science and Human Behaviour
Description: Aims to introduce students to the nature, scope, and concepts often used in the field of Human Movement. Examines movement behaviors often adopted by individuals and appreciates mobility factors in overcoming problems of sedentariness and inactivity.
Introduces students to basic human anatomy and physiology. Explores how these two subjects affect movement and analysis in sport and injury rehabilitation.

Course: Neuromuscular Systems in Health and Wellness
Description: Teaches students the neuromuscular and skeletal systems and their role in providing highly organized, flexible, and complex movements. Also teaches students to appreciate the structure and function of the skeletal system, the system of joints (the articular system), and the muscular system as facilitators of movement.

Course: Exercise and Physical Activity for diverse (special) population
Description: Provides students with an understanding of the unique physical, physiologic, and behavioral characteristics that require special consideration for exercise testing, exercise prescription, and training. Applies recommended procedures for exercise testing and prescription for three non-diseased special populations â€“ children, the elderly, and pregnant women.
Provides students with in-depth knowledge and understanding of the benefits of physical activity in the prevention and treatment of various health conditions of growing concern worldwide.
Introduces students to the cardiorespiratory system's anatomy and physiology. Discusses responses of the cardiorespiratory system in sports and games.

Introduces students to advanced concepts in exercise physiology and health-related issues. Helps understand the health implications of training-induced physiological adaptation and advanced concepts on the physiology of physical training, conditioning, and adaptation.

Course: Clinical Exercise Physiology and Orthopaedic Rehabilitation
Description: Applies exercise physiology principles and clinical applications associated with a wide range of diseases and disabilities.

Course: Orientation to PBL, Biokinetics and Recreation and Leisure Studies programme
Description: Introduces students to the three programs in the Center and to the teaching methodology adopted by the School of Health Sciences.

Course: Foundation of Human Movement Science and Human Behaviour
Description: Aims to introduce students to the nature, scope, and concepts often used in the field of Human Movement. Examines movement behaviors often adopted by individuals and appreciates mobility factors in overcoming problems of sedentariness and inactivity.
Language proficiency, communication writing skills

Course: Foundations of Recreation and Leisure Services
Description: Introduces students to the concepts, scope, and nature of leisure and recreation. Understands the vital roles recreation and leisure play in solving social problems and appreciates the values of recreation and leisure.

Introduces students to outdoor recreation as a sub-phenomenon of the larger recreation and leisure phenomenon, with added emphasis on the natural element, its psychological influence, and social significance.

Course: Recreation and Leisure for diverse population (vulnerable groups)
Description: Introduces students to different approaches when designing recreation and leisure activities for diverse populations like pregnant women, elderly people, and children.

Course: Ethics and Legal aspects of Recreation and Leisure
Description: Introduces students to the body of knowledge that helps them manage ethics and legal risks in recreation and in their everyday lives.

Course: Therapeutic Recreation, Leisure and Wellness Education
Description: Discusses techniques used as interventions by therapeutic recreation specialists and the recreation therapeutic process to bring about changes in the client and clientâ€™s environment.

Course: Facility Design and Management for Recreation and Leisure Activity
Description: Teaches students how to design and manage sports and recreation facilities.
Assists students in understanding how humans regulate their thoughts, feelings, and emotions and how their behavior can become more effective. Understands how human emotions affect performance.

Course: Seminar in Recreation and Leisure Services
Description: Develops studentsâ€™ ability to critique articles, review scientific information, and prepare students for seminar presentations. Discusses intelligently on topics of current interest in biokinetics/exercise and sport science.

Course: Organization and Administration of Major Events
Description: Introduces students to concepts of organizing and administrating events in recreation and leisure sector.

Provides students with in-depth knowledge and understanding of the benefits of physical activity in the prevention and treatment of various health conditions of growing concern worldwide.

Course: Knowledge Bases of Sport and Exercise Science
Description: Introduces students to the nature, scope, and concepts of sport and exercise. Assists students in having an analytic understanding of Sport and Exercise Science as a human performance-enhancement sub-discipline.

Introduces students to advanced concepts in exercise physiology and health-related issues. Helps understand the health implications of training-induced physiological adaptation and advanced concepts on the physiology of physical training, conditioning, and adaptation.

Introduces students to the subject area of Kinanthropometry as an important area in understanding performance in sport and physical activity. Aims to assist students in acquiring skills in the measurement of various dimensions of the body based on anatomical landmarks and the application of measurement results to sports and physical activity.

Course: Seminar in Exercise and Sport Science
Description: Develops students' ability to critique articles and review scientific information in their fields of study. Prepares students to develop skills and ability in seminar presentations and to discuss intelligently topics of current interest in biokinetics/exercise and sport science.
Assists students to understand how humans regulate their thoughts, feelings, and emotions and how their behavior can become more effective. Aims to understand how human emotions affect performance.

Description: Applies exercise physiology principles and clinical applications associated with a wide range of diseases and disabilities.

Exposing students to the concepts of new learning principles and life skills. Topics include background and introduction of PBL, principles of learning in PBL, PBL process, characteristics of PBL, using PBL principles in problem solving, life skills (goal setting, time management, managing assignments and assessment, managing workload, basic helping skills, effective listening skills), and topics related to healthy living (relationships, HIV/AIDS, sexual transmitted diseases, trauma debriefing, assessment).

History, nature, and goals of psychology; introduction to research in psychology; Description of research approaches (quantitative and qualitative); biological bases of human behavior (brain and behavior); perception; cognitive psychology; learning; developmental psychology; personality; social psychology.

History and methods of the study of human development; physical development throughout the human life span; pregnancy; prenatal growth; infancy; cognitive development; theories of moral development; socio-emotional development; attachment and caregiver relationships; issues of identity, cultural roles, and gender identity; trauma.

Personality psychology and various opinions about personality; personality from different perspectives; depth psychological perspective; person-oriented approach; social cognitive approach; learning perspective; biological perspective; behaviorist and alternative approach; African personality; personality structure and development; person construct theory.

Comparing and contrasting multiple methodologies in qualitative and quantitative research; understanding research coherence; developing a research proposal; exposure to research approaches, designs, conceptualizing, operationalizing, sampling, data collection, data analysis, discussions, conclusions, reliability, validity, and trustworthiness; ethical aspects in research.

Foundations and historical influences of community psychology; definition of community psychology; basic values and theories of community psychology; understanding a sense of community; identifying social capital, social networks, and civic engagement; ecological frameworks; neighborhoods; diversity categories; stress, coping, and social support; resilience; approaches to social change; prevention and promotion programs; program and logic models.

Theory and practicals of neurodevelopmental disorders; bipolar disorders; trauma and stressor-related disorders; anxiety disorders; suicide; disruptive impulsive control and conduct disorders; substance-related and addictive disorders; somatic symptoms and related disorders; depressive disorders; schizophrenia spectrum and related disorders; obsessive-compulsive and related disorders; personality disorders; feeding and eating disorders; elimination disorders; dissociative disorders; sleep-awake disorders; sexual dysfunction; paraphilic disorders; neurocognitive disorders.

Understanding the technical aspects of psychological testing; application of norms; describing different assessment tools; administering psychological assessment measures; practice of psychological assessment; controlling the use of measures; competing values and ethical practices.

Understanding different theories/models of crisis and psychological counseling; trauma debriefing, including Critical Incident Stress Debriefing (CISD); core qualities of helping; psychological counseling strategies; cultural diversity in terms of trauma issues.

Scope of practice for a registered counselor within the context of the profession of psychology; exploration of ethical dilemmas relating to informed consent, confidentiality, multiple relationships, diversity and multiculturalism, psychological assessment, forensic psychology, etc.; understanding ethical theories of deontology and tele-ontology; different ethical frameworks for ethical decision-making; exposure to the Health Professions Act and the Scope of practice.

Course: Sports Skills Fundamentals and Physical Performance
Description: Aims to introduce students to selected games, sports (individual, dual or team), and physical activities for health and fitness development. Activities are selected based on factors including accessibility, availability, cost, facilities, equipment, and skill levels.

Course: Physical Conditioning for Sports, Exercise and Games
Description: Introduces students to basic concepts in conditioning, physical fitness, exercise, and physical activity. Develops skills for conditioning athletes prior to competition.

Course: Motor Learning, Motor Behaviour and Performance
Description: Teaches how humans learn skilled actions and how the principles of motor (movement) performance and learning can be useful in teaching, coaching, rehabilitation, and the design of performer-friendly equipment and work environment.
Introduces the basis of good nutrition, the importance of activity in weight control, and the contributions of fitness to fat metabolism and weight control.

Course: Therapeutic Recreation for Health and Wellness
Description: Discusses techniques used as interventions by therapeutic recreation specialists and the recreation therapeutic process for bringing about changes in the client and clientâ€™s environment.

Course: Assessment and Evaluation Techniques in Exercise and Physical Activity
Description: Teaches basic skills of quantifying certain body parameters (e.g. body mass, body fatness, body mass index, etc.) in relation to health status and sport performance.

Introduces students to basic physics, laws of dynamics and motion. Aims to acquire a basic understanding of the application of applied human anatomy and physiology and mechanical physics to human movement associated with sports, exercise, and physical activities.

Acquires knowledge and ability to design research problems. Provides training in data management skills and the application of appropriate bio-statistical techniques to specific research questions and data sets.

Course: Sports Medicine, Injury Assessment and Rehabilitation
Description: Teaches students to develop knowledge of common injuries in sports and other conditions. Acquires skills in assessing orthopaedic injuries/conditions and rehabilitation common in different sports and populations.

Description: Enables students to present the required mini-dissertation based on research done in their area of specialty.

Course: Budget and Resource Attainment in Recreation and Leisure Service
Description: Assists students in understanding the importance of budgeting and resource attainment in leisure service programming. Acquaints learners with various trends impacting budgeting and resource attainment in leisure service organizations.

Course: Managing Recreation, Parks and Leisure Services
Description: Educates learners as leisure managers on mechanisms to promote greater community liability through leisure services and programs, natural resource development, and tourism activities.

Course: Sport First Aid and Management of Injuries
Description: Introduces students to basic techniques used in providing first aid and managing injuries in different spheres of life.

Focuses on two aspects of recreation and leisure: Adventure Leadership and Recreation Programming and Planning. Teaches programming strategies, approaches, and methods for directing staff to achieve the aims and objectives of the organization.

Teaches students an understanding of the commercial leisure sector in providing leisure and recreation services. Introduction to the scope, characteristics, and management aspects of the commercial recreation and tourism industry.

Aims to learn the general overview and practical experiences on modalities for delivering quality recreation and leisure programs. Understands the roles and responsibilities of leisure service programsâ€™ supervisor/manager.
Introduces students to the basic rules of consultancy in Recreation and Leisure studies.

Course: Research Methods in Recreation and Leisure Services
Description: Acquires knowledge and ability to design research problems. Acquires training in data management skills and application of appropriate bio-statistical techniques to specific research questions and data sets.

Course: Research Project; Data Collection and Analysis
Description: Enables students to present the required mini-dissertation based on research done in their area of specialty.

Course: Practicum in Recreation and Leisure Services
Description: Acquires practical knowledge and technical know-how regarding the delivery of recreation and leisure services. Works closely with different communities to determine their recreation and leisure preferences.

At the end of the programme, a student will be able to present the required mini-dissertation based on research done in their area of specialty. This module provides the student with an excellent opportunity to implement ideas and knowledge gathered in theory and practical courses and conduct supervised research in the field of Biokinetics or Exercise and Sport Science.

Exposes students to experience in both clinical, laboratory, and field settings employing sport science practices and principles. Students may be sent on attachment to sports clubs/teams, physical fitness centres, and sports medicine clinics. They may also be assigned to the University Biokinetic Clinic.

Course: Management Process of Nursing School Workbook

Description: Integrate all theories learned in different modules and apply them simultaneously in a holistic approach when solving health and nutrition problems of communities.
Integrate all theories learned in different modules in the third level of study and apply them simultaneously in a holistic approach when solving health and nutrition problems of communities.

Collect data related to the research proposal developed in the third level; analyze and interpret data using appropriate tools; write the research report or min-dissertation following appropriate format.

The student will work in the food service unit applying principles of food management, planning and leading under supervision. The student will be placed in the food service unit for a period of eight weeks.

Student will be responsible for the promotion of nutritional health and prevention of nutrition-related disorders/ill health of groups, communities or population via sustainable and equitable improvements in the food and nutrition system.

Students will work at the community level with the aim of promoting the implementation of nutrition intervention programmes and associated skills which are critical for nutrition training at the community level.
